numbered_ace_sentences: 1. I noticed that legacy applicants were admitted at a considerably higher rate than non-legacy applicants.
2. This difference was irrespective of income.
3. I noticed that the admission chance for students with the greatest income was a little over two times the admission chance for students with the lowest income.
4. I think that this difference is insignificant compared to the admission rate of legacy students whose parent income rate is 99.9.
5. I wonder about the role of money in the admissions process of the school.
6. I ask whether there is evidence of favoritism in the admission of legacy students.
7. I ask what distinguishes legacy students from non-legacy students as superior applicants.
8. I ask whether the admission of legacy students depends on actions of alumni of these schools.
9. I am from an urban area.
10. Many of my peers are from the same urban area.
11. Many of my classmates are from the same urban area.
12. Many of my peers are not legacy students.
13. Many of my classmates are not legacy students.
14. Many of my peers do not have parents who were alumni.
15. Many of my classmates do not have parents who were alumni.
16. Admission is more difficult for these peers and classmates.
17. These peers and classmates are already at a disadvantage.
18. This disadvantage is due to circumstances beyond their control.
19. The headline is: Rags To Riches, Is Favoritism Ending Fair Chances?
